ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: It was a virtual classroom with lectures and breakout rooms for discussions.
Periodically, asynchronous classes were held. On these days we would submit work either individually or with a partner, but there were no corresponding recordings to watch,
group discussion
Live lectures were supplemented by individual meeting with the Teaching Fellow.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I gained a more solid foundation in Japanese in grammar structure, vocabularly, and kanji writing.
Advanced Japanese grammar structures and fewer than 100 additional kanji are learned. Some aspects of the course highlighted Japanese cultural traditions.
speaking ability
This semester of Japanese enhanced my knowledge of kanji, grammar, culture and speaking styles pertinent to various settings.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The professor was amazing and put so much effort into getting things graded quickly while also being willing to spend time to help! Overall, the professor helped to build a great environment that allowed me to not only feel comfortable participating and speaking up but allowed me to make friends virtually in class too!

The class size is very small, the work load was high and the teacher was incredibly interactive, all of which fostered rapid learning and retention. The weaknesses are negligible, but it is worth noting that the class depends on conversational prompts much of the time. This is helpful but becomes problematic when the prompts are unclear, especially when they are homework-based.

Despite our confinement to the digital realm, the structure of class, group projects, and peer review helped build a sense of community amongst the students and instructor. I also value how accessible our instructor was. There were also very good learning aids provided to supplement the textbook.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Breakout rooms were useful for this course to engage with classmates which ultimately helped reinforce our japanese skills.

The course was easily and perfectly adapted for the transition to online learning. The class has students write compositions on various collaborative platforms, which was a total success. However, towards the end of the course, students would end up alone with their conversational partners while conversational prompts were thoroughly exhausted. Therefore, the only downside of this format seems to be that it is probably more difficult for the professor to gauge when the class as a whole should move on from a given exercise.
I think it was difficult to do group work and cooperate via Zoom. Maybe we can replace the group works with individual works.
The frequent discussion exercises in break-out room worked well to facilitate our practice.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: If you want to continue Japanese, then yes!
If you are interested in advancing your Japanese skills, definitely take this course!
Yes, wholeheartedly. This class was extraordinarily fun despite being so much work, and that is largely thanks to the genial professor and the sense of community fostered by small class size.
Highly recommend!
Absolutely. The instructor guides the class through an exploration of Japanese language and culture that builds considerably on the first two semesters.
